pros: Colleagues were nice and helpful, worked on some very interesting projects, had the opportunity to branch out
cons: Average pay, technology not very up to date

job_title: Fieldwork Delivery Manager in Brentwood, England
pros: Lovely colleagues in my team Supportive line manager
cons: Leadership (senior) team making very poor decisions. Non collaborative environment. No progression Low pay

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner HRBP in London, England
pros: Flexible, friendly staff, nice place to work
cons: No clear progression, lack of communication

review_title: Interesting work but don’t value staff
pros: Opportunities to work on a range of projects, with movement possible across different research focuses
cons: Do not value staff, either in terms of recognising contributions made or in terms of providing a competitive benefits package Lack of strategic thinking about the balance of work that’s taken on and how some teams in the organisation are substantially under resourced Benefits for new starters are worse compared to employees who have been at the organisation for longer (e.g. annual leave entitlement 30 days for people who started before date X, 25 days for those who started on/after that date)

pros: Home based working and Flexible
cons: Badly managed, should be more target focused and driven but too reactive instead. Company has gone from being under staffed, almost too much work to handle to making staff redundant in one year.

pros: - Organise your own time. - Everyday is different.
cons: - Wages can be unstable. - Wage dependent on whether people want to be interviewed.

pros: Interesting work and hybrid working.
cons: Not much sense of organisational culture and little to zero activities for staff to harness this. Pay not great and HR slow to act to review this.

job_title: Project Manager in Kingston upon Thames, England
pros: Organised Flexible Managers allow you to get on with the job, but also provide a good level of support when required.
cons: I cannot think of any cons really they are a well-established and professional organisation.

review_title: Great people, great opportunities to develop
pros: -Good training -Great people - Lots of responsibility over project tasks
cons: - Some overtime/long hours - Repetitive tasks

job_title: Field Performance Manager in London, England
pros: homebased role with flexibility of hours
cons: top heavy management structure, little opportunity to progress

pros: The colleagues are nice and the company is moving to a new location which will be much better. Easy work.
cons: No room for progression. Low pay and the company increases pay by pennies.

job_title: IT Support Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: One big happy family. Management is well run.
cons: Career Progression limited. Its a charity company after all.

job_title: Field Interviewer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: Work when you want, subject to 26 hour min per week
cons: Impossible to meet targets at all

pros: Flexible work environment. Bonuses. Training and Development
cons: Need to meet targets. Penalty for not meeting targets.

pros: Flexible working hours were good.
cons: Flexible working pay, Flexible working pay

pros: The only thing I can think of is that it’s a good stepping stone to something better. I’d recommend anyone getting a junior position there to be prepared to leave within 2 years. Don’t get stuck!
cons:
Oh dear:
- super low pay and massive inequalities and unfairness when it comes to pay on the same positions 
- massive favouritism 
- complete exploitation of junior staff (low pay but very high expectations and responsibility)
- long, unpaid hours 
- very poor management and low progression/raise opportunities 
- discrimination and bullying occurrences 

Generally I’d stay away unless you want your soul crashed and mental health ruined. I know too many people including me who left this place half a person.

job_title: Market Research Interviewer in London, England
pros:
Flexible working hours.
Interesting projects.
Meeting nice respondents.
cons:
Bad management.
Long hours.
Poor pay for hours involved.

job_title: Social Research Interviewer in London, England
pros: Flexible working dealing direct with a wide range of the public
cons: As a interviewer receive no acknowledgement of work done well. You are treated as at the bottom of the pile by senior management. You have minimum choice of work given despite being not directly employed so have all the disadvantages of a casual worker without the choice the status is supposed to be given. The current stance by management to adapt to a challenging time is unhelpful and is detrimental to results.

pros: Good work culture, friendly staff
cons: Lots of admin, large bureaucracy

pros: the company offers many flexible benefits
cons: Salary could be better and more competitve

pros: Being outdoors, on my own.
cons: Bullying management, favouritism, lower pay than promised.

pros: Nice company to work for.
cons: Progression non existent. People have to leave to make them twitch.

pros:
Flexible working
Work life balance
Interesting projects
Friendly team/co-workers
cons:
Hot desking -not enough desks in London office
Lack of promotion/progression within some departments

job_title: Social Research Interviewer in London, England
pros: It was OK, people nice but work boring.
cons: Some interviews ridiculously long. Some areas I had to go to were run down and decrepit.

pros: Flexible hours, work from home
cons: Inconsistent allocation of work on occasion

review_title: Interesting work, but rigid structures stifle creativity
pros: Great place to learn robust research methods and ethical approaches, and as a qual researcher I got to work on some fascinating studies for a mix of government clients and charitable funders. Good opportunities to get involved in things going on across the organisation, such as ethics committees and delivering training, if you want to do more than just the basics of your job description.
cons: Most commonly, you're delivering studies for clients and there's very little flexibility to attend meetings and events to share findings outside of what the client funds. This means that there's not much opportunity to develop a professional profile in your subject area. While NatCen are strong on robust methodologies, the downside of this is that there's little openness to innovation and creativity in methods.

pros: The  work is very interesting and it is great to have such control over your working patterns and approach to the job
cons: It is very unpredictable and difficult to work out how much you will be getting paid. The fees from some of the interviews are very disappointing. I was told it would average out to £10 p/h but I'm not convinced I am making as much as that.

review_title: Toxic workplace where bullying and favouritism is rife.
pros: Great range of research projects to work on, some of which are commissioned by high profile organisations and government departments. Technically challenging work.
cons:
Lack of upward mobility for researchers at lower grades and lack of development opportunities, which keeps you in a vicious cycle. 

It often feels like it’s not hard work that gets you places in this organisation but who you are friendly with. Compared to other social research positions, pay, especially for lower grade researchers is very low. Line managers vary significantly, but some are unprofessional, difficult to work with and uninvested in your professional development.

pros: Informal working environment, flexibility with hours (although that is going now), working with highly skilled people, training of staff.
cons: Direction from CEO gone. Not sure what our goal is. Spends money that's not needed. Two London sites don't work well. Time waste on travelling between offices. Technology backwards!

job_title: Social Research Interviewer in London, England
pros: Excellent management and support at field level.
cons:
Poor technical (IT) support systems.
Some poorly designed research and interview materials.

pros: Interesting and challenging projects, knowledgeable and experienced colleagues, flexible working is the norm.
cons: Bullying is often left unaddressed and has led to low morale and high turnover of staff, particularly in certain teams. Prospective applicants should take heed.

pros:
Some staff are really friendly
Free tea and coffee, parking spaces available. 
Opportunities to progress if you want to.
cons:
Offices are dirty and rundown
Some bullying goes on unchecked and managers are too friendly with some of their employees, leaving others unable to make a complaint against them.
Wages very low even for a charity.

review_title: the work has purpose and benefits society
pros: Nature of day to day work is interesting, busy, sometimes too busy, challenging, holidays and location
cons: lack of prospects, pay and high work pressure leads to reduced quality and lack of development time

review_title: good work environment but low salaries
pros: nice people, many interesting projects to work on
cons: low salaries, few possibilities for development. Senior managers only worry about winning more projects, but dont consider the people (researchers) who work on them.

review_title: Much to recommend it, but recently lost its way.
pros: Brilliant people, varied, interesting and valuable work.
cons: Many of the best people have left. Current management weak.

pros: A lot of responsibilities and exposure to a wide mix of projects
cons: Often mundane work, teetering on grunt work. A lot of moments of downtime with little to do. Poor supervision.

pros:
NatCen does some of the UK's most important and interesting research.
It's a lovely place to work. Great people, a collegiate atmosphere and a socially conscious organisation.
cons: Had a few lean years, but is now on the up.

pros: Good terms and conditions ,
cons: Lack of development  and training. Lack of resources for further training and development

pros: if you like to talk rubbish to people for no money then great
cons: endless hours of ADMIN and driving and hastling people at their doors uninvited for slave wages ...maybe average 2 quid an hour

pros: Involvement in various different projects
cons: Organisational communication can be improved

pros: Methodological rigour and collegiate atmosphere
cons: Low salaries, over worked and low recognition

pros: Friendly environment for parents and academics
cons: Space office could improve and should
